{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Nalin Mehta''' is a leading Indian social scientist, journalist and writer. He is Executive Editor, Times of India- Online.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Exchange4medianewsservice |title=The Times Of India Promotes Dr Nalin Mehta As Executive Editor- Online |url=https://www.exchange4media.com/digital/the-times-of-india-promotes-dr-nalin-mehta-as-executive-editor-online_87043.html |website=Exchange4media |publisher=Exchange4media |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> He has been Associate Professor at [[Shiv Nadar University]];<ref>Shiv Nadar University, School of Humanities and Social Sciences Staff Pages, 2016 [http://snu.edu.in/humanitiessocialsciences/nalin_mehta_profile.aspx Shiv Nadar University]</ref> Consulting Editor<ref>{{cite web |last1=indiantelevision.com team |title=He has taken a break from broadcast media for a while.... http://www.indiantelevision.com/television/tv-channels/people/nalin-mehta-joins-toi-delhi-as-consulting-editor-140811 |url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/television/tv-channels/people/nalin-mehta-joins-toi-delhi-as-consulting-editor-140811 |website=indiantelevision.com |publisher=indiantelevision.com |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> with [[The Times of India]];<ref>[http://blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/author/nalinmehta/ Times of India author profiles]</ref> and Founding Editor of the international journal South Asian History and Culture (Routledge) as well as the Routledge ‘South Asian History and Culture’ book series.<ref>[https://www.routledge.com/South-Asian-History-and-Culture/book-series/SAHC Routledge South Asian History and Culture Series]</ref> He has also been Co-Director of Times LitFest Delhi <ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/litfest/litfest-delhi/directors/litfest_directors/47674213.cms Times Lit Fest Delhi official website]</ref> and has previously been Managing Editor of India's Today Group's English TV news channel, Adjunct Professor at [[Indian Institute of Management Bangalore]] and held senior positions with the [[Global Fund]] in Geneva, Switzerland, and [[UNAIDS]].<ref>[http://nalinmehta.in/ Nalin Mehta's official website]</ref>
==Early life and education== Mehta studied at the prestigious [[Scindia School]], Gwalior, where he finished as School Captain and editor of the ''Scindia School Review''.<ref>Nalin Mehta, [http://www.scindia.edu/new_website/admin/upload/74qilaquotes_mag_15_July_2009.pdf "The Computer Man"], "Qila Quotes: the Scindia School Quarterly", July 2009, p.9</ref> A Commonwealth-DFID scholar, he obtained an MA in International Relations from [[University of East Anglia]] and a Ph.D in political science from [[La Trobe University]] in [[Melbourne]].<ref>Australia India Institute, University of Melbourne, Argumentative Indian conference: speaker profile, [http://www.argumentativeindian.org/speakers-chairs/nalin-mehta/], 2012</ref>
==Career== Star TV CEO Uday Shankar has called Mehta "probably the best media academic in India" <ref>Faculty in spotlight: profile on Nalin Mehta's Behind a Billion Screens published by Shiv Nadar University [http://snu.edu.in/pdf/Faculty-in-Spotlight-Nalin-Mehtas.pdf]</ref> and the media guru Robin Jeffrey has described his work as "remarkable for being both a distinguished academic and an experienced journalist".<ref>[http://nalinmehta.in/books/billion-screens-television-tells-modern-india Quoted on backjacket of Behind a Billion Screens]</ref> Mehta's latest book ''Behind a Billion Screens: What Television Tells Us About Modern India'', long-listed for Business Book of the Year by Tata Literary Live 2015 <ref>[http://www.tata.com/media/releasesinside/Tata-Literature-Live-The-Mumbai-LitFest-announces-longlists-for-four-coveted-book-awards Tata Literary Live]</ref> is a highly acclaimed <ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/14/world/asia/television-that-few-want-to-watch.html?_r=0 New York Times, 14 May 2015]</ref> national non-fiction bestseller.<ref>[http://snu.edu.in/pdf/Faculty-in-Spotlight-Nalin-Mehtas.pdf SNU Faculty in Spotlight, 2015]</ref>
Mehta's first book ''India on Television'', widely acclaimed as a seminal, "impeccably researched" <ref>Amulya Gopalakrishan, [http://www.indianexpress.com/news/catch-the-waves/334401/0 "Catch The Waves"], "The Indian Express", 13 July 2008</ref> and "authoritative scholarly study" of the politics and business of [[television in India]],<ref>[http://archive.financialexpress.com/news/tube-diktats/358208/1 Financial Express, 7 Sep. 2008]</ref> was awarded the Asian Publishing Convention Award for Best Book in 2009.<ref>IANS, [http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/business/marketing-campaign-for-the-white-tiger-wins-asian-prize_100219408.html "Marketing Campaign for 'The White Tiger' Wins Asian Prize], 17 July 2009</ref>
His social history of Indian sport, ''Olympics: The India Story'' co-authored with historian Boria Majumdar, was welcomed as a "pioneering, long awaited"<ref>K. Arumugam, [http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/BooksReviews/Olympics-The-India-Story/Article1-328809.aspx "Olympics: The India Story"], "The Hindustan Times", 4 August 2008</ref> work of history in the press and as a "triumph of Olympian proportions".<ref>[http://www.stick2hockey.com/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleOID=1440 Gulu Ezekeil in New Indian Express, 10 Aug. 2008]</ref> India's most well known sociologist [[Ashis Nandy]] called it " the first comprehensive, scholarly and yet lively account of India's experiences with the Olympics".<ref>Ashis Nandy, quoted on back cover of Olympics: The India Story. New Delhi, HarperCollins, 2012, 3rd edition</ref>
Mehta and Majumdar joined together again to write ''Sellotape Legacy'', a detailed account of the politics, economics and disaster of the Delhi Commonwealth Games in 2010. Former Indian sport minister [[Mani Shankar Aiyar]] called it a "blazing expose" and a "thorough, well-researched, sober and absorbingly well-written indictment of Everything You wanted to Know about CWG [Commonwealth Games] but were Afraid to Ask.".<ref>Mani Shankar Aiyar, [http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?267208 "A Pratfall, Mr Kalmadi?"], "Outlook", 4 October 2010</ref>
Mehta's other major work includes ''Gujarat Beyond Gandhi'', a jointly edited anthology of critical essays which looked at 60 years of politics and social change in Gujarat.<ref>V. Venkatesan, [http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl2823/stories/20111118282307500.htm "Enigma of Gujarat"], "Frontline", 5–18 Nov 2011</ref>
Mehta has been Managing Editor of India Today's English news channel (2013–14),<ref>[http://snu.edu.in/humanitiessocialsciences/nalin_mehta_profile.aspx SNU Faculty in Spotlight, 2015]</ref> Deputy News Editor and prime-time anchor with [[Times Now]].<ref>Routledge, 2013 [http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780415556125/ Author profile in Routledge books]</ref> and a political correspondent and anchor with [[NDTV]].<ref>Ajitha GS, [http://www.timeoutdelhi.net/timein/time_in_details.asp?code=42&source=1 "Small wonder"], "Time Out", July 2012</ref> For NDTV, he covered the [[2002 Gujarat violence]]<ref>Amita Malik, [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020308/art-trib.htm#3 "Mauling the Media"], "The Tribune", 8 March 2002</ref> and subsequent state assembly elections,<ref>Nalin Mehta, [http://193.146.160.29/gtb/sod/usu/$UBUG/repositorio/10291938_Mehta.pdf "Modi and the Camera: The Politics of Television in the 2002 Gujarat Riots], "South Asia: Journal of South Asian Studies", Dec. 2006, see footnotes on pages 405,408,411,413</ref> the [[2001 Gujarat earthquake]], the assassination of the royal family in [[Kathmandu]] and several Indian state elections including [[Chhattisgarh]] and [[Punjab]].<ref>Amita Malik, [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020215/art-trib.htm#4 "On the Election Trail"], The Tribune, 15 February 2002</ref>
Alongside leadership positions in the media industry and international development agencies, Mehta has held several visiting appointments at universities and institutions in Australia, Switzerland, Singapore and India. These include [[National University of Singapore]], [[Australian National University]], Canberra, La Trobe University, Melbourne, and the International [[Olympic Museum]] in Lausanne, Switzerland.<ref>[http://snu.edu.in/humanitiessocialsciences/nalin_mehta_profile.aspx Shiv Nadar University]</ref>
==Awards and recognition== * Asian Publishing Award for Best Book on Asian Media/Society for India on Television, 2009.<ref>IANS, [http://www.afaqs.com/news/company_briefs/index.html?id=41691_The+White+Tiger+Campaign+win+the+Asian+multimedia+publishing+awards+2009 "The White Tiger Campaign win the Asian multimedia publishing awards 2009"], 20 July 2009</ref> * Government of Australia Alumni Excellence Award for Media and Entertainment, 2010.<ref>Government of Australia press release [http://www.indiaprwire.com/pressrelease/education/2010101265023.htm "Inaugural Australian Alumni Excellence Awards Presented"], 9 October 2010</ref> * Long-listed for Tata Literary Live Best Business Book of the Year, 2015, for Behind a Billion Screens: What Television Tells Us About Modern India <ref>[http://www.tata.com/media/releasesinside/Tata-Literature-Live-The-Mumbai-LitFest-announces-longlists-for-four-coveted-book-awards Tata Literary Live, 2015]</ref>
==Books== * ''Behind a Billion Screens: What Television Tells Us About Modern India'', (HarperCollins, 2015), Longlisted for Business Book of the Year by Tata Literary Live, national non-fiction bestseller"<ref>[http://snu.edu.in/pdf/Faculty-in-Spotlight-Nalin-Mehtas.pdf Shiv Nadar University, 2015]</ref> * ''India on Television: How Satellite TV Has Changed the Way We Think and Act (Harper Collins, 2008). Winner of Asian Publishing Award 2009 for Best Book'' <ref>[http://www.news18.com/news/books/the-white-tiger-nominated-for-asian-publishing-awards-320632.html]</ref> * ''Sellotape Legacy: Delhi and the Commonwealth Games 2010'', with Boria Majumdar (Harper Collins, 2010).<ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/a-pratfall-mr-kalmadi/267208 Outlook]</ref> * ''Olympics: The India Story'', with Boria Majumdar (Harper Collins, 2008, 2012), republished as India and the Olympics (Routledge, 2009)''<ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/a-pratfall-mr-kalmadi/267208 Outlook]</ref> * ''Television in India: Satellites, Politics and Cultural Change'' (Editor. Routledge, 2008, 2009)<ref>[https://www.routledge.com/products/9780415546430 Routledge]</ref> * ''Gujarat Beyond Gandhi: Politics, Conflict and Society'', with Mona G. Mehta (Editor. Routledge, 2010, 2011).<ref>[https://www.routledge.com/products/9780415556125 Routledge]</ref> * The Changing Face of Cricket: From Imperial to Global Game, with Dominic Malcolm & Jon Gemmell (Editor. Routledge, 2010).<ref>[http://www.tandfebooks.com/doi/book/10.4324/9781315869315 Routledge]</ref>

{{for|the language|Nambikwara language}} {{infobox ethnic group |group=Nambikwara |population=1,150 (2000)<ref name=ethno/> |popplace={{Flag|Brazil}} ({{Flag|Mato Grosso}}) |rels=[[Christianity|Christian]], [[Animist]]<ref name=ethno/> |langs=[[Nambikwara language|Nambikwara]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]<ref name=ethno/> |related=none }} The '''Nambikwara''' (also called '''Nambikuára''') is an [[indigenous people of Brazil]], living in the [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]]. Currently about 1,200 Nambikwara live in [[Indigenous territory (Brazil)|indigenous territories]] in the Brazilian state of [[Mato Grosso]] along the [[Guaporé River|Guaporé]] and [[Juruena River|Juruena]] rivers. Their villages are accessible from the Pan-American highway.<ref name="Kroeker, 2001, p.1">Kroeker, 2001, p.1</ref>
==Name== The Nambikwara are also known as the Alaketesu, Anunsu, Nambikwara, or Nambiquara people.<ref name=ethno>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nab "Nambikuára, Southern."] ''Ethnologue.'' Retrieved 9 March 2012.</ref>
==Language== The Nambikwara speak the [[Southern Nambikuára language]], which is a [[Nambiquaran language]]. A dictionary and grammar have been written for the language, which is written in the [[Latin script]].<ref name=ethno/>
==History== The Nambikwara were first contacted in 1770 but did not experience prolonged contact with Europeans until the early 20th century, when Brazilian army official Marechal [[Cândido Rondon]] passed through Nambikwara territory to extend the telegraph lines. He estimated that there were around 10,000 Nambikwara. Shortly after contact with European Brazilians [[epidemic]]s of [[measles]] and smallpox decimated the population to only 500 around 1930.<ref name="Kroeker, 2001, p.1"/>
The culture of the Nambikwara was the subject of studies by [[France|French]] [[anthropologist]] [[Claude Lévi-Strauss]], which were later analyzed by French philosopher [[Jacques Derrida]] in his work ''Of Grammatology''.

{{short description|A sting operation in West Bengal targeting high ranking Trinamul politicians.}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} The '''Narada sting operation''' was a [[sting operation]] carried out by [[Mathew Samuel]] targeting high-ranking officials and politicians of the [[All India Trinamul Congress]] (AITC). It showed several politicians and a high-ranked police officer accepting cash-bribes in exchange for providing unofficial favors to a company.
Performed in 2014 for the Indian news-magazine ''[[Tehelka]]'', it was published on a private website months before the 2016 [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2016|West Bengal Assembly elections]].
{{As of|June 2017}}, the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI), [[Enforcement Directorate]] (ED) and a parliamentary ethics committee are probing the case. The Trinamool Congress has rejected the allegations and has claimed that the money was received in way of donations.
== Background == {{Main|Mathew Samuel}} [[File:This is the photo of Mathew Samuel.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Mathew Samuel]] [[Mathew Samuel]] was the former managing editor of ''[[Tehelka]],'' a news magazine known for its [[investigative journalism]] and [[sting operations]]. He was one of the main principals behind the sting operation ''[[Operation West End|West End]]'' which spawned a miniature democratic crisis in 2001 and eventually led to the resignation of Defence Minister [[George Fernandes]] and later, the conviction of [[Bharatiya Janata party|Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP)]] President [[Bangaru Laxman]].<ref name=outlook>{{cite web|title=After Eleven Years, It Stings To Say This...|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?280773|publisher=[[Outlook magazine|Outlook]]|last=Samuel|first=Mathew|date=14 May 2012}}</ref>
Around 2014, the ''Tehelka'' administration floated the idea of a sting operation in an effort "to come back into the market with a good story; with a bang".<ref name=paid/> Samuel and his team initially opted for either [[Madhya Pradesh]] or [[Himachal Pradesh]], but the opportunities never materialized. The ruling government in Madhya Pradesh was led by BJP and Samuel did not wish to be identified as a journalist who solely targeted the BJP governments whilst the political atmosphere of Himachal Pradesh was too quiet to be conducive for a sting operation.
It was around this time the [[Saradha Group financial scandal]] surfaced in [[West Bengal]]. Samuel felt that the corruption unearthed until then was only "the tip of the iceberg" and the team accordingly zeroed in on the politicians of West Bengal as their target.<ref name="paid">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nationalheraldindia.com/news/2017/04/29/indian-rupee-80-lakh-for-the-narada-sting-was-paid-by-mp-kd-singh-mathew-samuel-ed-tmc|title=₹ 80 lakh for the Narada sting was paid by MP KD Singh|access-date=2 June 2017|date=29 April 2017|work=[[The National Herald (India)|The National Herald]]}}</ref>
== Operation == In an interview with ''[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]]'', Mathew Samuel said he was inspired by Israeli [[Mossad]] officer [[Michael Harari|Mike Harari]]. He had asked a friend to create a cover for him as a high official of the fictitious Chennai-based firm Impex Consultancy Solutions. An [[Aadhaar]] card in the name of ''Santhosh Shankaran'' was issued for Samuel and social-media profiles were created.<ref name="spy">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160403/jsp/7days/story_77941.jsp|title=7 Days: I spy with my little eye...|date=3 April 2016|access-date=2 June 2017|language=en|work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]]}}</ref>{{efn|Some commentators have noted that it's another reminder to the sad state of affairs that can be easily exploited to generate a fake AADHAR number.}}
While trying to gauge the mood of the public, they chanced upon a taxi-driver who introduced them to a person who was locally known as 'Tiger'.<ref name="paid" /><ref name="spy" /> Samuel claims that 'Tiger' initially introduced him to Iqbal Ahmed, the then deputy mayor of the [[Kolkata Municipal Corporation]], and [[Indian Police Service|IPS]] officer S. M. H. Mirza. They were then supposedly acquainted with Sultan Ahmed (Iqbal’s brother), [[Subrata Mukherjee]], [[Bobby Hakim|Firhad Hakim]] and [[Aparupa Poddar]]. Mirza also introduced him to [[Madan Mitra]] and [[Mukul Roy]]. And, each of these meetings proliferated in the development of further connections. In Samuel's words: "It was almost like a chain reaction".<ref name="paid" />
In the 52 hours of footage photographed by Samuel and his colleague Angel Abraham around 2014, many prominent politicians resembling [[Member of Parliament (India)|Members of Parliament]] Mukul Roy, [[Saugata Roy]], [[Kakoli Ghosh Dastidar]], [[Prasun Banerjee|Prasun Bannerjee]], [[Suvendu Adhikari]] and Sultan Ahmad, and state ministers Madan Mitra, Subrata Mukherjee and Firhad Hakim, and Iqbal Ahmed<ref name="spy" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160315/jsp/bengal/story_74595.jsp|title=THE STING IN FULL|work=The Telegraph|access-date=31 July 2018}}</ref> were seen accepting alleged bribes in the form of wads of cash in exchange for doing unofficial favours for Impex Consultancy Solutions floated by Samuel himself.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160317/jsp/frontpage/story_74983.jsp#.WN3xQvl97IU|title=Narada referred to LS ethics committee|last=|first=|date=17 March 2016|work=The Telegraph|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Funding == Whilst Samuel initially claimed that [[K. D. Singh (politician)|K. D. Singh]], a [[Rajya Sabha]] MP of the [[Trinamool Congress]] and majority owner of Tehelka, was in the dark about the entire operation and he was a 'lone-wolf',<ref name="spy" /> he later retracted his claims and asserted that Singh knew and funded the entire operation.<ref name="paid" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/state/k-d-singh-ordered-me-to-do-the-sting-operation-on-tmc-leaders-says-mathew-samuel-1.582948|title=তৃণমূল সাংসদ কে ডি সিংহের নির্দেশেই স্টিং অপারেশন, বিস্ফোরক ম্যাথু|date=20 March 2017|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=bn}}</ref> He claimed that the budget of the operation was initially set at {{INRConvert|2500000|year=2017}} but was later increased to {{INRConvert|8000000|year=2017}}, as the number of potential targets increased vastly.<ref name="paid" /> The police subsequently filed a criminal case against Singh expecting that a large part of the sum might have been harvested from his [[Alchemist Group|chit fund business]] in West Bengal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Politics/w857MuEba6xgj5yd0eZ2vO/Narada-sting-Kolkata-Police-files-criminal-case-against-TMC.html|title=Narada sting: Kolkata Police files criminal case against TMC MP Kanwar Deep Singh|last=Majumdar|first=Arkamoy Dutta|date=23 March 2017|work=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]|access-date=30 July 2018}}</ref> However, Singh refuted his involvement with any aspect of the sting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/kd-singh-says-he-has-no-relation-with-narada-sting-operation-1.730210|title=নারদে জড়িত নই, দাবি কেডি সিংহের|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=27 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>
== Release == A certain part<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/west-bengal-news/kolkata-news/cbi-is-investigating-the-unedited-footage-of-narada-sting-operation/articleshow/57803829.cms|title=সিবিআইয়ের হাতিয়ার নারদের জোড়া ফুটেজ|last=|first=|date=24 March 2017|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> of the sting operation tapes were released to the public through the website ''naradanews.com'' after a nearly two-year lag.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/narada-after-saradha-11-top-leaders-of-tmc-in-huge-bribe-controversy-dgtl-1.332461|title=নারদের স্টিং অপারেশন, ঘুষ বিতর্কে জড়ালেন তৃণমূলের ১১ শীর্ষ নেতা|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/public-opinion-on-narada-sting-operation-1.332896|title=নারদ নারদ|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/furore-as-sting-video-shows-trinamool-leaders-taking-cash/article8354564.ece|title=Furore as sting video shows Trinamool leaders taking cash|date=15 March 2016|work=The Hindu|access-date=30 July 2018|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> This was attributed by Samuel to the inertia of the Tehelka administration in publishing the tapes.<ref name=paid/>
== Reactions == The Trinamool Congress initially denied any connection with the sting operation, alleging it to be a product of political conspiracy and the video to be entirely forged.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/elections/westbengal2016/sting-operation-shows-tmc-leaders-taking-cash-smear-campaign-says-tmc/article8351926.ece|title=Furore as sting video shows Trinamool leaders taking cash|last=Bagchi|first=Suvojit|date=14 March 2016|work=The Hindu|access-date=30 July 2018|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/cm-still-feels-that-nobody-is-involved-in-narada-and-saradha-scam-from-her-party-1.646125|title=অসম্মান করতেই নারদ, সারদা|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> Derek O'Brien, the Trinamool spokesperson as well as party supremo-[[Mamata Banerjee]] alleged it to be a [[smear campaign]] by the opposition manifesting from vendetta-politics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abplive.in/india-news/trinamool-congress-leaders-caught-accepting-money-in-a-sting-video-305973|title=Sting claims TMC leaders took cash, party 'dismissive'|first=|date=15 March 2016|work=ABP live|access-date=5 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/mamata-terms-narada-sting-political-vendetta/article8386926.ece|title=Mamata terms Narada sting political vendetta|date=23 March 2016|work=The Hindu|access-date=30 July 2018|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> Later, the Trinamool Congress claimed that the money received was in the form of a donation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/the-money-of-narada-is-just-vote-subscription-not-bribe-says-mamata-1.719694|title=নারদের টাকা ‘ভোটের চাঁদা’, মন্তব্য মমতার|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=27 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> The subsequent CBI investigations were branded as witch-hunts and to be a product of vested political interests.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/mamata-banerjee-slams-cbi-over-narada-sting-issue-1.635689|title=সিবিআইকে একহাত নিলেন মুখ্যমন্ত্রী|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/west-bengal-news/narada-case-fir-filed-against-12-top-tmc-leaders/articleshow/58232824.cms|title=এতে দোষ প্রমাণ হয়না, সাফ কথা মমতার|last=|first=|date=18 April 2017|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> Trinamool MP [[Dinesh Trivedi]] was noted to be a dissenting voice and asked for the resignation of the accused.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/elections/west-bengal/election-news/dinesh-tribedi-thinks-leaders-in-narada-video-must-resign-1.342141|title=Dinesh tribedi thinks leaders in narada video must resign - Anandabazar|website=www.anandabazar.com|language=en|access-date=28 July 2018}}</ref>
The [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)|Communist Party of India]] (CPIM) and the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) organised mass protests demanding the resignation of the politicians involved.<ref> *{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/narada-sting-case-opposition-demands-removal-of-tainted-west-bengal-ministers/articleshow/57689598.cms|title=Narada sting case: Opposition demands removal of "tainted" West Bengal ministers|last=|first=|date=17 March 2017|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} *{{Cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/state/left-to-demonstrate-in-demand-to-arrest-tmc-leaders-in-narada-scam-1.599401|title=নারদ কাণ্ডে অভিযুক্তদের হেফাজতে চাই, ফের রাস্তায় বামেরা|date=18 April 2017|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=bn}} *{{Cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/state/bjp-to-walk-rally-against-tmc-on-narada-issue-1.583548|title=দ্বিধা কাটিয়ে নারদে এ বার পথে বিজেপি|date=21 March 2017|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=bn}} *{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/opposition-on-narada-news-sting-operation-dgtl-1.332500|title=নারদ-কাণ্ডে একযোগে মুখ্যমন্ত্রীর ইস্তফা দাবি করলেন বিরোধীরা|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>
== Fallout and investigations == [[File:Mamata banerjee.jpg|thumb|upright=1|left|[[Mamata Banerjee]], [[Chief Minister of West Bengal]] and leader of the All India Trinamool Congress.]] === Political === There was apparently no fallout from the sting operation in the 2016 assembly elections, contrary to expectations of Indian media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/elections/westbengal2016/nano-amby-and-the-bumps-on-west-bengals-path/article8402518.ece|title=Nano, Amby and the bumps on West Bengal’s path|last=Dutta|first=Indrani|date=27 March 2016|work=The Hindu|access-date=30 July 2018|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/politics/narada-sting-operation-will-it-dent-mamata-banerjee-s-popularity-117032300266_1.html|title=Narada sting operation: Will it dent Mamata Banerjee's popularity?|last=Dutt|first=Ishita Ayan|date=24 March 2017|work=Business Standard India|access-date=30 July 2018}}</ref> The AITC government returned to power with an absolute majority. This was proclaimed by [[Mamata Banerjee]] in her victory speech after the elections as an endorsement of the honesty of the party.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/narada-videos-a-year-after-the-sting-trinamool-feels-the-pain/article18275943.ece|title=Narada videos: A year after the sting, Trinamool feels the pain|date=28 April 2017|work=The Hindu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en|last1=Deepalakshmi|first1=K|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Legal === On 17 June 2016, the state initiated the first legal measures and ordered a probe by [[Kolkata Police Force|Kolkata police]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Mamata-Banerjee-orders-police-to-probe-Narada-sting-operation/articleshow/52799779.cms|title=Mamata Banerjee orders police to probe Narada sting operation|last=|first=|date=17 June 2016|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/cp-rajiv-kumar-will-investigate-narada-sting-1.413966|title=রাজ্যেরও নারদ-তদন্ত, দায়িত্বে রাজীব|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/silence-another-investigation-is-on-process-narada-scam-1.414528|title=চোপ, তদন্ত চলছে|last=বন্দ্যোপাধ্যায়|first=অঞ্জন|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> Soon, three [[Public interest litigation in India|public-interest litigations]] from the [[Indian Congress party]] and BJP were filed in Calcutta High Court asking for an impartial probe in light of the influential positions held by the accused.<ref>{{cite news|title=Narada News sting operation: 3 PIL filed in Calcutta High Court, ED to begin probe|url=http://indiablooms.com/ibns_new/news-details/N/18622/narada-news-sting-operation-3-pil-filed-in-calcutta-high-court-ed-to-begin-probe.html|accessdate=12 May 2017|work=Indiablooms.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/state/pil-seeking-cbi-probe-in-narada-case-1.334541|title=সিবিআই চেয়ে জনস্বার্থ মামলা, প্রতিবাদ পথেও|date=17 March 2016|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=bn}}</ref> The State of West Bengal, along with the accused, asked for a probe by the state investigation team or by a special investigation team, while the petitioner pushed for a probe by a central agency.
The local police was also accused of heckling Samuel, after summoning him for running alleged extortion-rings and interrogating him over the sting-issue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/west-bengal-news/kolkata-news/master-plan-of-police-manoj-and-mathew-are-in-trouble/articleshow/57784944.cms|title=পুলিশের কুশলী চালে বিড়ম্বনায় মনোজ-ম্যাথু|last=|first=|date=23 March 2017|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/mathew-samuel-complains-that-police-harassed-him-1.629617|title=পুলিশি হেনস্থার নালিশ ম্যাথুর|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/sting-operation-cbi-summons-mathew-samuel-1.630073|title=এ বার ফোন-সহ তলব ম্যাথুকে|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>
The state subsequently initiated its own probe which booked Samuel under multiple sections of the [[Indian Penal Code|IPC]] 469 (forgery to harm reputation), 500 (defamation), 120(B) (criminal conspiracy) etc.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/State-counters-Narada-There-was-no-demand-for-bribe/articleshow/53777675.cms|title=State counters Narada: There was no demand for bribe|last=|first=|date=19 August 2016|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On 5 August 2016, the High Court stayed the state probe for ''ad infimum'', observing that the police cannot run a concurrent investigation along with a court-monitored probe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/west-bengal-news/kolkata-news/narada-case-state-police-accused-narada-cases-says-nishita-mhatre/articleshow/57699744.cms|title=পুলিশকে পুতুল বলে তিরস্কার|last=|first=|date=18 March 2017|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/HC-stays-Kolkata-Police-probe-into-Narada-sting/articleshow/53561934.cms|title=HC stays Kolkata Police probe into Narada sting|last=|first=|date=5 August 2016|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
On 18 March 2017, the state initiated disciplinary proceedings against S. M. H. Meerza, a high-ranking officer in the [[Indian Police Service]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/state-took-action-against-meerza/articleshow/57697315.cms|title=State took action against SMH Meerza|last=|first=|date=18 March 2017|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> He was the lone person (of all those who were filmed in the video tape to have accepted cash-bribe), to have been subject to some form of sanction by the state.<ref>{{Cite news|title=|last=|first=|date=18 March 2017|work=Bartaman|access-date=}}</ref>
==== CBI Investigation ==== The CBI was subsequently asked to probe the case after the court raised doubts about the impartiality of the probe being conducted by the West Bengal Police<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/cbi-to-probe-narada-sting-case-calcutta-high-court/articleshow/57698788.cms|title=CBI to probe Narada sting case: Calcutta high court|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017}}</ref> and the footage was certified as authentic by the Central Forensic Laboratory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Central-lab-report-Most-of-Narada-tapes-untampered/articleshow/53626549.cms|title=Central lab report: Most of Narada tapes untampered|last=|first=|date=10 August 2017|work=The Times of India|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Whilst the state objected to the handling of the probe to CBI, a bench of the Court, presided by Chief Justice [[Nishita Nirmal Mhatre|Nishita Mhatre]] subsequently held that whilst the motives of Samuel and the legality of his actions might be debatable, that does not undermine the findings of the sting, in any manner and an investigation by an impartial agency shall be proceeded with.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sangbadpratidin.in/kolkata/narada-sting-political-leaders-taking-money-not-desirable-says-kolkata-high-court/|title=স্যামুয়েল নয়, নারদ কাণ্ডে ভিডিও ফুটেজকেই গুরুত্ব হাই কোর্টের|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Supreme Court of India also rejected an appeal by the state, allowing the CBI probe to continue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/supreme-court-upholds-verdict-of-cbi-investigation-in-narada-case-dgtl-1.583723|title=সিবিআই তদন্ত বহাল, সুপ্রিম কোর্টে ধাক্কা রাজ্যের|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>

2018|language=bn}}</ref>
[[Aparupa Poddar]] confessed to have taken an amount of 3 lakh INR but claimed innocence as to any ulterior motive.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/narada-sting-trinamool-mp-admits-taking-rs-3-lakh-bribe/articleshow/60963863.cms|title=Narada sting: Trinamool MP ‘admits taking Rs 3 lakh bribe’ - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=27 July 2018}}</ref> She also claimed to have worked per the advice of Iqbal Ahmed.<ref name=":1" /> Iqbal Ahmed admitted to have accepted the cash but asserted to have utilized it in the development of a [[Maidan (Kolkata)|Maidan]] based sports-club, [[Mohammedan S.C. Meerza initially refuted to have accepted any cash but later conceded to the veracity of the tape and claimed that he has donated the entire amount to an orphanage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/west-bengal-news/kolkata-news/narada-sting-cops-grill-ips-officer-record-statement/articleshow/59306522.cms|title=কোন অনাথ আশ্রমে মির্জার টাকা|last=|first=|date=25 June 2017|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>
The investigation subsequently hit a road-block as certain portions of the footage (a prior to the) were found to be missing from the submitted footage.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/authenticity-of-narada-footage-stalls-cbi-investigations-dgtl-1.803962|title=ম্যাথুর দেওয়া ফুটেজ নিয়েই প্রশ্ন, নারদ তদন্ত বিশ বাঁও জলে!|last=মণ্ডল|first=সিজার|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> Samuel claimed to have deleted the non-necessary parts of the footage, whilst transferring them to the laptop from his i-phone and to have forgotten the password for the i-phone folder, which contained the cut-out portions.<ref name=":6" /> The CBI subsequently contacted [[Apple Inc.]] to retrieve the contents of the folder but whilst denying to share the password citing privacy requirements, they confirmed that the entire sting-footage have indeed been shot by an i-phone.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/state/apple-declined-to-share-password-of-mathew-phone-dgtl-1.816152|title=ম্যাথিউ-এর ফোনের পাসওয়ার্ড সিবিআইকে দিল না অ্যাপল|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref> Recent developments indicated that the CBI was in touch with professional hackers to gain access to the folder.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/calcutta/cbi-hired-us-hackers-to-decipher-mathew-phone-password-dgtl-1.816754|title=এ বার মার্কিন হ্যাকারদের শরণাপন্ন সিবিআই|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=28 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eisamay.indiatimes.com/nation/get-information-on-matthews-phone-the-cbi-is-going-to-america/articleshow/63197553.cms|title=ম্যাথুর ফোনের জট কাটাতে আমেরিকায় পা ফেলছে সিবিআই|last=|first=|date=7 March 2018|work=Eisamay|access-date=30 July 2018|language=bn}}</ref>

=== Ethics committee === Since the sting operation involved Members of Parliament, a [[Lok Sabha]] ethics committee was also set up to initiate a probe to determine if the persons committed a breach of privilege of the house concerned.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160317/jsp/frontpage/story_74983.jsp|title=Narada referred to LS ethics committee|last=|first=|date=17 March 2016|work=The Telegraph|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The committee sat only once after the incident.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/national/lk-advani-rises-question-on-disciplinary-committee-on-the-issue-if-narada-scam-1.529808|title=আগে সংসদ, পরে নীতি কমিটি: আডবাণী|date=12 November 2016|work=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|access-date=24 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=bn}}</ref>

'''Näcip Ğayaz ulı Cihanov''' — [[Tatar language|Tatar Cyrillic]]: Нәҗип Гаяз улы Җиһанов, pronounced {{IPA-tt|næˈʑip ɣʌˌjɑzuˈlɯ ʑiˈhɑnəf|}}; {{lang-ru|Нази́б Гая́зович Жига́нов}}; anglicised as Najip Jihanov or, more usually, '''Nazib Gayazovich Zhiganov''' — was a [[Tatar]] composer, teacher and statesman. He was born on {{OldStyleDate|15 January|1911|2 January}} in [[Uralsk]];<ref name="Baker's Bio">{{cite book|last=Slonimsky|first=Nicolas|title=Baker's Biographical dictionary of musicians.|year=1978|publisher=Schirmer Books|location=New York|isbn=0-02-870240-9|edition=6th|page=1944|chapter=Zhiganov, Nazib}}</ref> he died on 2 June 1988.
Cihanov wrote eight operas (notably ''Altınçäç'' and ''[[Musa Calil|Cälil]]''), three ballets, 15 symphonies, other symphonic works (''Qırlay'', ''Suite on Tatar Themes'', ''Näfisä'', ''Symphonic novellas'', and ''Symphonic Songs'' among them), the cantata ''Republic of Mine'' (1960), camera-instrumental compositions, and romances and songs.
Granted the titles of [[People's Artist of the USSR]] (1957) and [[Hero of Socialist Labour]] (1981), Cihanov served as artistic leader of the Tatar Opera and Ballet from 1941 to 1943, chairman of [[Tatarstan]]'s Composers Union from 1939 to 1977, and rector of [[Kazan Conservatory]] from 1945 to 1988. He was made professor in 1953; Kazan Conservatory was renamed in his honor in 2000. Importantly, Cihanov was one of the founders of the State Symphony Orchestra of Tatarstan.<ref>http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:s_78pUwEO8sJ:en.tatarstan-symphony.com/news/show/72+&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us</ref> In his capacity as statesman, he served as a deputy in the [[Supreme Soviet of RSFSR]] (1951–1959), the [[Tatar ASSR]] (1963–1967, 1977–1988), and indeed the [[Soviet Union]] (1966–1970).
==Operas== *''Qaçqın'' (1939) *''İrek'' (1940) "Freedom"<ref>"Ирек" ("Свобода", 1940)</ref> *''Altınçäç'' (1941) "The golden-haired girl"<ref>Russian transliteration "Алтынчеч", Russian title "Золотоволосая", lyrics by [[Musa Cälil]]</ref> *''İldar'' (1942)<ref>"Ильдар"</ref> *''Tüläk'' (1945)<ref>"Тюляк"</ref> *''Namus'' (1950) "Honour"<ref>Russian transliteration "Намус" (Russian title "Честь")</ref> *''Cälil'' (1957) based on the life of poet [[Musa Cälil]].<ref>[http://www.belcanto.ru/dzhalil.html "Джалиль" (1957, либр. А. Файзи). Article in Russian]</ref>

{{good article}} [[File:Octavia-Hill-by-Sargent.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|alt=portrait of a Victorian woman of middle age facing the artist, head slightly to the right|Octavia Hill by [[John Singer Sargent]], 1898]] '''Octavia Hill''' (3 December 1838 – 13 August 1912<ref name="dnb" />) was an English social reformer, whose main concern was the welfare of the inhabitants of cities, especially London, in the second half of the nineteenth century. Born into a family with a strong commitment to alleviating poverty, she herself grew up in straitened circumstances owing to the financial failure of her father. With no formal schooling, she worked from the age of 14 for the welfare of working people.
Hill was a moving force behind the development of social housing, and her early friendship with [[John Ruskin]] enabled her to put her theories into practice with the aid of his initial investment. She believed in self-reliance, and made it a key part of her housing system that she and her assistants knew their tenants personally and encouraged them to better themselves. She was opposed to municipal provision of housing, believing it to be bureaucratic and impersonal.
Another of Hill's concerns was the availability of open spaces for poor people. She campaigned against development on existing suburban woodlands, and helped to save London's [[Hampstead Heath]] and [[Parliament Hill Fields]] from being built on. She was one of the three founders of the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]], set up to preserve places of historic interest or natural beauty for the enjoyment of the British public. She was a founder member of the [[Charity Organization Society|Charity Organisation Society]] (now the charity Family Action) which organised charitable grants and pioneered a home-visiting service that formed the basis for modern social work. She was a member of the [[Royal Commission on the Poor Laws and Relief of Distress 1905-09#The Royal Commission on the Poor Law|Royal Commission on the Poor Laws]] in 1905.
Hill's legacy includes the large holdings of the modern National Trust, several housing projects still run on her lines, a tradition of training for housing managers, and the museum established by the Octavia Hill Society at her birthplace.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Octavia Hill was the daughter of James Hill, corn merchant, follower of Owenism<ref name=Phil>James Hill, father to Octavia Hill, Follower of Owenism and founder of newspaper "The star in the East"[http://www.wisbech-society.co.uk/octavia.html "Octavia Hill: The Wisbech Society and Preservation Trust"]</ref> and banker, and his third wife, Caroline Southwood Smith. He had been widowed twice, and had six children (five daughters and a son) from his previous marriages.<ref name=smith>Smith, Mark K., [http://www.infed.org/thinkers/octavia_hill.htm "Octavia Hill: Housing, Space and Social Reform"], The Encyclopaedia of Informal Education, 2008, accessed 14 November 2010.</ref> He had been impressed by the writings on education of Caroline Southwood Smith, the daughter of Dr [[Thomas Southwood Smith]], a pioneer of sanitary reform.<ref name=dnb>Darley, Gillian, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-33873?rskey=rnxST6&result=1 "Hill, Octavia (1838–1912)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 1 November 2010</ref> He had engaged Caroline as a governess for his children in 1832, and they were married in 1835, three years before Octavia was born in [[Wisbech]], [[Cambridgeshire]], her father's eighth daughter and ninth child.<ref name=smith/> The family's comfortably prosperous life was disrupted by James Hill's financial problems and his mental collapse. In 1840 he was declared bankrupt. Caroline Hill's father gave the family financial support, and took on some of Hill's paternal role.<ref name=dnb/>
Southwood Smith was a health and welfare reformer concerned with a range of social issues including child labour in mines and the housing of the urban poor. Caroline Hill held similar views on social reform, and her interest in progressive education, influenced by [[Johann Heinrich Pestalozzi]], and Southwood Smith's daily experience in his work at the [[London Hospital]] in the [[East End of London|East End]] inspired Octavia Hill's concern for the poorest in early Victorian London. She received no formal schooling: her mother educated the family at home.<ref name=dnb/> [[File:Ruskin-SouthwoodSmith-Maurice-Mayhew.jpg|thumb|left|200px|alt=four head and shoulder portraits of Victorian men|Early influences on Octavia Hill – top: [[John Ruskin]] and [[Thomas Southwood Smith]]; below: [[Frederick Denison Maurice|F.D. Maurice]] and [[Henry Mayhew]]]] The family settled in a small cottage in [[Finchley]], now a north London suburb, but then a village.<ref name=dnb/> Octavia Hill was impressed and moved by [[Henry Mayhew]]'s ''[[London Labour and the London Poor]]'', a book that portrayed the daily lives of slum dwellers. She was also strongly influenced by the theologian, [[Anglican]] priest and social reformer [[Frederick Denison Maurice|F. D. Maurice]], who was a family friend. She began her work on behalf of London's poor by helping to make toys for [[Ragged school]] children, and serving as secretary of the women's classes at the Working Men's College in [[Bloomsbury]] in central London.<ref name=wohl>Wohl, A. S., "Octavia Hill and the Homes of the London Poor", ''The Journal of British Studies'', University of Chicago Press, Vol. 10, No. 2 (May, 1971), pp. 105–31 {{DOI|10.1086/385612}}</ref>
A co-operative guild providing employment for "distressed gentlewomen" accepted Hill for training in glass-painting when she was 13. When the work of the guild was expanded to provide work in toy-making for Ragged school children, she was invited, at the age of 14, to take charge of the workroom.<ref name=mann>Mann, Peter H., "Octavia Hill: An Appraisal", ''The Town Planning Review'', Vol. 23, No. 3 (October 1952), pp. 223–37</ref> The following year she began working in her spare time from the guild as a copyist for [[John Ruskin]] in [[Dulwich Art Gallery]] and the [[National Gallery]]. She was deeply aware of the dreadful living conditions of the children in her charge at the guild.
Her views on encouraging self-reliance led to her association with the [[Charity Organisation Society]] (COS), described by Hill's [[biographer]] Gillian Darley as "a contentious body which deplored dependence fostered by kindly but unrigorous philanthropy … support to the poor had to be carefully targeted and efficiently supervised. Later in life, however, she began to think the COS line … was over-harsh."<ref name=dnb/>
Hill was short, like all her family, and indifferent to fashion. Her friend [[Henrietta Barnett]] wrote: "She was small in stature with long body and short legs. She did not dress, she only wore clothes, which were often unnecessarily unbecoming; she had soft and abundant hair and regular features, but the beauty of her face lay in brown and very luminous eyes, which quite unconsciously she lifted upwards as she spoke on any matter for which she cared. Her mouth was large and mobile, but not improved by laughter. Indeed, Miss Octavia was nicest when she was made passionate by her earnestness."<ref name=wyatt2/> Barnett also spoke of Hill's streak of ruthlessness. [[Gertrude Bell]] called Hill despotic. Later in Hill's life, the Bishop of London, [[Frederick Temple]], encountered her at a meeting of the Ecclesiastical Commissioners, and wrote, "She spoke for half an hour … I never had such a beating in all my life."<ref>Leak, Adrian, [http://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2010/13-august/faith/for-houses-and-green-space "For houses and green space"] ''[[The Church Times]]'', 10 August 2010, accessed 14 November 2010</ref>
===Housing for the poor=== [[File:London-slum-1880s.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Victorian photograph of the exterior of a London slum property|A [[Marylebone]] slum in the nineteenth century]] Parliament and many concerned reformers had been attempting to improve the housing of the working classes since the early 1830s. When Hill began her work, the model dwelling movement had been in existence for twenty years, royal and select committees had sat to examine the problems of urban well-being, and the first of many tranches of legislation aimed at improving working class housing had been passed.<ref name=wohl/> From Hill's point of view these had all failed the poorest members of the working class, the unskilled labourers. She found that their landlords routinely ignored their obligations towards their tenants, and that the tenants were too ignorant and oppressed to better themselves.<ref name=wohl/> She tried to find new homes for her charges, but there was a severe shortage of available property, and Hill decided that her only solution was to become a landlord herself.
John Ruskin, who was interested in the co-operative guild, knew Hill from her work as his copyist and was impressed by her.<ref name=mann/> As an [[aesthete]] and a humanitarian he was affronted by the brutal ugliness of the slums.<ref>Wyatt, pp. 1–2</ref> In 1865, having inherited a substantial sum of money from his father, he acquired for £750 the leases of three cottages of six rooms each in Paradise Place, [[Marylebone]].{{#tag:ref|Now known as Garbutt Place.<ref name=smith/>|group= n}}
Ruskin placed these houses, which were "in a dreadful state of dirt and neglect",<ref name=times/> under Hill's management. He told her that investors might be attracted to such schemes if a five percent annual return could be secured.<ref name=dnb/> In 1866 Ruskin acquired the freehold of five more houses for Hill to manage in Freshwater Place, Marylebone.<ref name=wyatt2>Wyatt, p. 2</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' recorded, "The houses faced a bit of desolate ground occupied by dilapidated cowsheds and manure heaps. The needful repairs and cleaning were carried out, the waste land was turned into a playground where Mr. Ruskin had some trees planted."<ref name=times>''The Times'' obituary, 15 August 1912, p. 7</ref>
After being improved the properties were let to those on intermittent and low incomes. A return of five per cent on capital was obtained as promised to Ruskin; any excess over the five per cent was reinvested within the properties for the benefit of the tenants. Rent arrears were not tolerated, and bad debts were minimal. As Hill said, "Extreme punctuality, and diligence in collecting rents, and a strict determination that they shall be paid regularly, have accomplished this."<ref name=wyatt2/> In consequence of her prudent management, Hill was able to attract new backers, and by 1874 she had 15 housing schemes with around 3,000 tenants.<ref name=smith/>
Hill's system was based on closely managing not only the buildings but the tenants; she insisted, "you cannot deal with the people and their houses separately."<ref name=wohl/> She maintained close personal contact with all her tenants, and was strongly opposed to impersonal bureaucratic organisations and to governmental intervention in housing.<ref name=morrell>Morrell, Caroline, "Octavia Hill", ''The Economic History Review'', New Series, Vol. 52, No. 1 (February 1999), p. 158 {{DOI|10.1111/1468-0289.00122}}</ref> In her view, "municipal socialism and subsidized housing" led to indiscriminate demolition, re-housing schemes, and the destruction of communities.<ref name=wohl/>
===Housing management=== At the heart of the Octavia Hill system was the weekly visit to collect rent. From the outset, Hill conceived this as a job for women only. She and her assistants (who included [[Emma Cons]] and [[Eva McLaren]]) combined the weekly rent collection with checking every detail of the premises and getting to know the tenants personally, acting as early social workers.<ref name=dnb/> At first Hill believed, "Voluntary workers are a necessity. They are better than paid workers, and can be had in sufficient numbers."<ref name=mann/> Later, she found it expedient to maintain a paid workforce.<ref name=dnb/> Her system required a large staff. Rent was collected on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday mornings. Rent accounts were balanced in the afternoons and arrangements were made with contractors for repairs. On Thursdays and Fridays arrears were pursued, contractors' invoices paid, new tenancy lettings and tenants' moves organised.<ref name=wyatt3/>
If any of Hill's assistants had spare time, whether during normal working hours or in frequent voluntary after-hours working, it was used to promote tenants' associations and after-work and children's after-school clubs and societies.<ref name=wyatt3>Wyatt, p. 3</ref> In 1859, Hill created the Southwark detachment of the [[Army Cadet Force]], its first independent unit, which gave training along military lines for local boys.<ref name=dnb/> Hill considered that such an organisation would be more like the "real thing" than such existing outfits as the [[Church Lads' and Church Girls' Brigade|Church Lads' Brigade]] and therefore more attractive to young men "who had passed the age of make-believe". She invited a serving officer of the [[Derbyshire Regiment]] to set up the company, and such was its popularity that its numbers had to be capped at 160 cadets.<ref name=smith/>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#EEEEEE |salign=center | quote =It would be wrong to assume that Octavia's principle of housing management was guided simply on the question of the payment of rent. Despite being up to date with his rent, a tenant was surprised to receive Notice to Quit, because he would not send his children to school and had overcrowded his rooms. Octavia's response to his complaint that he didn't owe any rent was that it was not the only thing she insisted upon. In her view, she could not allow anything so wrong as the neglect of children and overcrowding to continue where she had the power to prevent it!| source = R.J. Wyatt <ref name=wyatt2/>| align=left| width=33%}} Hill's principles were summed up in an article of 1869: "Where a man persistently refuses to exert himself, external help is worse than useless." She was an outspoken critic of the principles of "[[outdoor relief]]" or the [[Speenhamland system]] of poor relief as operated by various Poor Law Boards. Because these systems did not encourage recipients to work, she regarded them as "a profligate use of public funds."<ref name=wyatt2/> Under her methods, personal responsibility was encouraged. She insisted on dealing with arrears promptly; she appointed reliable caretakers; she took up on references of prospective tenants, and visited them in their homes; she paid careful attention to allocations and the placing of tenants, with regard to size of families and the size and location of the accommodation to be offered; and she made no rules that could not be properly enforced.<ref name=wyatt2/>
In 1884, the Ecclesiastical Commissioners recognised her enlightened approach and turned to her to manage and reform their slum properties in South London, which were notorious for poverty and petty crime. Hill turned these estates into model properties, which still paid a return on investment. These estates continued to be let to tenants at affordable rents throughout much of the twentieth century, even when rent control was relaxed and open market rents substantially increased.<ref name="Spencer-Thomas2018">{{Cite web | title = Octavia Hill (1838-1912) | last = Spencer-Thomas | first = Owen | work = Owen Spencer-Thomas | date = 2018 | accessdate = 2018-02-06 | url = http://sayitstraight.co.uk/local-history/biographies/octavia-hill-1838-1912/ | quote = }}</ref>
An American admirer described her as "ruling over a little kingdom of three thousand loving subjects with an iron scepter twined with roses."<ref>Bremner, Robert H. "'An Iron Scepter Twined with Roses': The Octavia Hill System of Housing Management", ''The Social Service Review'', Vol. 39, No. 2 (June 1965), The University of Chicago Press, pp. 222–31 {{JSTOR|30017593}}</ref> Although Hill drove her associates hard, she drove herself harder. In 1877, she collapsed and had to take a break of several months from her work. Darley ascribes a number of contributory causes: "chronic overwork, a lack of delegation, the death of her close friend Jane Senior, the failure of a brief engagement",{{#tag:ref|Hill's fiancé was one of her helpers, the barrister and later M.P. [[Edward Bond (politician)|Edward Bond]].<ref name=dnb/>|group= n}} as well as an attack on her by John Ruskin.{{#tag:ref|Ruskin, by now mentally unstable, had reacted fiercely when Hill opposed his plans to sell his properties to the St. George's Company, an organisation that she regarded as financially dubious.<ref name=dnb/><ref>Darley (2004) ''quoted'' by Smith</ref>|group= n}} The Hill family found a companion for her, Harriot Yorke (1843–1930). Yorke took on a great amount of the everyday work that had caused Hill's collapse. She remained her companion until Hill's death. A further palliative was the building of a cottage, at [[Crockham Hill]] near [[Sevenoaks]] in Kent, where they could take breaks from their work in London.<ref name=smith/>
===Open spaces=== [[File:Wicken Lode1.JPG|thumb|alt=photograph of countryside scene, with water bounded by grass|[[Wicken Fen]] acquired by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] in 1899]] [[File:Footpath on Hampstead Heath - geograph.org.uk - 53758.jpg|thumb|right|alt=outdoor photograph of a large, grassed open space, with trees|[[Hampstead Heath]] – saved by Octavia Hill and others]] Among Hill's concerns was that her tenants, and all urban workers, should have access to open spaces. She believed in "the life-enhancing virtues of pure earth, clean air and blue sky."<ref>[http://octaviahill.org/conservation.html "Conservation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401202153/http://octaviahill.org/conservation.html |date=1 April 2010 }} The Octavia Hill Society, accessed 14 November 2010</ref> In 1883 she wrote: {{quote|There is perhaps no need of the poor of London which more prominently forces itself on the notice of anyone working among them than that of space. ... How can it best be given? And what is it precisely which should be given? I think we want four things. Places to sit in, places to play in, places to stroll in, and places to spend a day in. The preservation of [[Wimbledon and Putney Commons|Wimbledon]] and [[Epping Forest|Epping]] shows that the need is increasingly recognised. But a visit to Wimbledon, Epping, or [[Windsor Great Park|Windsor]] means for the workman not only the cost of the journey but the loss of a whole day's wages; we want, besides, places where the long summer evenings or the Saturday afternoon may be enjoyed without effort or expense.<ref>Hill 1883, VII. Space for the People, pp. 89–90</ref>|}}
She campaigned hard against building on existing suburban woodlands, and helped to save [[Hampstead Heath]] and [[Parliament Hill Fields]] from development.<ref name=dnb/> She was the first to use the term "Green Belt" for the protected rural areas surrounding London. Three hills in Kent (Mariners Hill, [[Toys Hill]] and [[Ide Hill]]) which she helped to protect from development form part of the belt.<ref name=hillsocwho>[http://octaviahill.org/who-was-octavia-hill.html "Who Was Octavia Hill?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601102028/http://octaviahill.org/who-was-octavia-hill.html |date=1 June 2010 }} The Octavia Hill Society, accessed 15 November 2010</ref>
In 1876 Hill became the treasurer of the Kyrle Society, founded in that year by her eldest sister, [[Miranda Hill|Miranda]], as a "Society for the Diffusion of Beauty". Under the slogan "Bring Beauty Home to the Poor" it aimed to bring art, books, music and open spaces into the lives of the urban poor.<ref>Hill, Octavia, "Oratorios for the People", ''The Musical Times'', December 1884, p. 717 {{JSTOR|3356074}} {{subscription}}</ref> For a short period it flourished and expanded, and although it declined after a few years, it was a template for the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]], 20 years later.<ref name=dnb/>
Before that, however, Hill was engaged in a campaign in 1883 to stop the construction of railways from the quarries in the fells overlooking [[Buttermere]], in the English [[Lake District]], with damaging effect on the unspoilt scenery. The campaign was led by Canon [[Hardwicke Rawnsley]], who secured the support of Ruskin, Hill, and [[Robert Hunter (National Trust)|Sir Robert Hunter]], solicitor to the [[Commons Preservation Society]].<ref name=rawnsleydnb>Murphy, Graham. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/37884 "Rawnsley, Hardwicke Drummond (1851–1920)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 15 November 2010 {{subscription}}</ref> From 1875 onwards, Hunter had been Hill's legal adviser on the protection of open spaces in London. Both he and Rawnsley, building on an idea put forward by Ruskin, conceived of a trust that could buy and preserve places of natural beauty and historic interest for the nation.<ref name=hunterdnb>Chubb L.W., rev. Graham Murphy, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/34064 "Hunter, Sir Robert (1844–1913)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 16 November 2010 {{subscription}}</ref>
On 16 November 1893, Hill, Hunter and Rawnsley met in the offices of the Commons Preservation Society and agreed to launch such a trust. Hill suggested that it should be called "The Commons and Gardens Trust", but the three agreed to adopt Hunter's suggested title, the "National Trust".<ref name=smith/> Under its full formal title, the National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty was inaugurated the following year.<ref name=hunterdnb/> The trust was concerned primarily with protecting open spaces and endangered buildings of historic interest; its first property was [[Alfriston Clergy House]] and its first [[nature reserve]] was [[Wicken Fen]].<ref>[http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-trust/w-thecharity/w-thecharity_our-past/w-history_trust-timeline.htm "Timeline"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204142224/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-trust/w-thecharity/w-thecharity_our-past/w-history_trust-timeline.htm |date=4 February 2011 }}, The National Trust, accessed 16 November 2010</ref>
===Later years=== The number of homes managed by Hill continued to grow. Although Ruskin had turned against her in a bout of mental instability, she found a new supporter, the [[Church Commissioners|Ecclesiastical Commissioners]], who handed over to her the management of their housing estates in several poor areas of south London.<ref name=dnb/> By the end of the nineteenth century, Hill's women workers were no longer unpaid volunteers but trained professionals. Hill's influence spread beyond the properties under her own control. Her ideas were taken up and copied, with her enthusiastic support, in continental Europe and the United States of America.<ref name=wohl/> [[Beatrice Webb]] said that she "first became aware of the meaning of the poverty of the poor," while staying with her sister, who was a rent collector for Octavia Hill in the East End.<ref name=wohl/> [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]'s daughter, [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom|Princess Alice of Hesse-Darmstadt]], was taken incognito on a tour of some of Hill's properties, and she translated Hill's ''Homes of the London Poor'' into German.<ref name=wohl/><ref>{{Cite journal|pmc=1662917|year=1990|author1=Lowry|first1=S|title=Much from little|journal=BMJ : British Medical Journal|volume=300|issue=6733|pages=1207–1208|doi=10.1136/bmj.300.6733.1207}} (free access)</ref>
Among those whom Hill trained was her assistant and secretary, Maud Jeffery, who was later engaged by the [[Commissioners of Crown Lands]] to run new housing estates in London on Octavia Hill's lines.<ref>"The Housing Business Group", ''Housing News'', Autumn 2004, [[The Crown Estate]], 2004.</ref> Even some local authorities, despite Hill's distrust, followed her model: some of the earliest examples of municipal council housing, at [[Kensington]] and [[Camberwell]], were run on her lines, with the acquisition of working class houses, and their gradual improvement, without evictions or demolitions.<ref name=wohl/>
[[File:Octavia hill.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Hill in 1881]]
Despite her opposition to interference by national or local government in the provision of housing, Hill had to cope with the newly created [[London County Council]] and the involvement of the council and other local authorities in providing housing for the poor. In 1884 a royal commission on the housing of the working classes was set up, but the prime minister, [[William Ewart Gladstone|W.E. Gladstone]], and his ministerial colleagues vetoed a proposal to include Hill among the members of the commission.<ref name=dnb/>{{#tag:ref|Gladstone approved of Hill's principles but thought her difficult as a person. Had Hill's appointment not been vetoed, she would have been the first woman member of a royal commission. In the event she was one of the commission's key witnesses. She served as a member of a later royal commission, on the Poor Laws, in 1905.<ref name=dnb/><ref name=who>[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U187121 "Hill, Miss Octavia",] ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 11 Oct 2010 {{subscription}}</ref>|group= n}} The municipal authorities quickly surpassed her in the number of properties under their management.
A.S. Wohl notes that in the 1880s Hill had about £70,000 worth of property under her management, and at the end of her career she was managing the dwellings of "perhaps three or four thousand people at the most."<ref name=wohl/> The London County Council, by contrast, had a budget of £1,500,000 for its programme of rehousing London's poor in 1901–02.<ref>Hill, Octavia, [http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=TT19010427.2.24 "Housing of the Poor"], ''The Times'', 4 March 1901, p. 11</ref>
Hill was opposed to other reforms that came about in the early part of the twentieth century. She was against female suffrage on the grounds that "men and women help one another because they are different, have different gifts and different spheres."<ref>''[[The Times]]'', 15 July 1910, p. 9</ref> She also believed that provision of social services and old-age pensions by the government did more harm than good, sapping people's self-reliance.<ref name=dnb/>
Hill died from [[cancer]] on 13 August 1912 at her home in [[Marylebone]], at the age of 73.
==Legacy and memorials== [[File:Octavia_Hill_(plaque).jpg|thumb|right|alt=photograph of a memorial blue plaque|Plaque at Redcross Way in South London]] When [[John Singer Sargent]]'s portrait of her was presented by her fellow-workers in 1898, Hill made a speech in which she said, "When I am gone, I hope my friends will not try to carry out any special system, or to follow blindly in the track which I have trodden. New circumstances require various efforts, and it is the spirit, not the dead form, that should be perpetuated. ... We shall leave them a few houses, purified and improved, a few new and better ones built, a certain amount of thoughtful and loving management, a few open spaces..." But, she said, more important would be "the quick eye to see, the true soul to measure, the large hope to grasp the mighty issues of the new and better days to come – greater ideals, greater hope, and patience to realize both."<ref>[[Sydney Cockerell|Cockerell, Sir Sydney]], "Octavia Hill", ''The Times'', 28 February 1935, p. 13</ref>
The Horace Street Trust, founded by Hill, became a model for many subsequent housing associations and developed into the present trust that bears her name, Octavia Housing. Today it owns several of the homes, including Gable Cottages, designed by Elijah Hoole, who worked with Hill for many years.<ref name=legacy>[http://octaviahill.org/octavia-s-legacy.html "Legacy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528084208/http://octaviahill.org/octavia-s-legacy.html |date=28 May 2010 }}, Octavia Hill Society, accessed 14 November 2010</ref> Hill's determination to provide community space can still be seen in the shape of the Red Cross site in Southwark (1888), among others. The Octavia Hill Society website states that with a community hall, and soundly maintained attractive houses, Hill here anticipated the fundamental ingredients of town planning by some 15 years.<ref name=legacy/>
The [[Settlement movement|Settlement Movement]] (creating integrated mixed communities of rich and poor) grew directly out of Hill's work. Her colleagues [[Samuel Augustus Barnett|Samuel]] and Henrietta Barnett, founded [[Toynbee Hall]], the first university-sponsored settlement, which together with the Women's University Settlement (later called the Blackfriars Settlement) continues to serve local communities.<ref name=legacy/> Overseas, Hill's name is perpetuated in the Octavia Hill Association in [[Philadelphia]], a small property company founded in 1896 to provide affordable housing to low and middle-income city residents.<ref name="davis/">{{cite journal|last1=Davis|first1=Allen|last2=Sutherland|first2=John F.|title=Reform and Uplift Among the Philadelphia Negroes: the Diary of Helen Parrish, 1888|journal=Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography|date=October 1970|volume=94|issue=4|pages=496–99|url=https://journals.psu.edu/pmhb/article/view/42674/42395}}</ref><ref name=legacy/>
Women who had trained under Hill formed the Association of Women Housing Workers in 1916. This later changed its name to the Society of Housing Managers in 1948. After merging with the Institute of Housing Managers in 1965, the society became the present day [[Chartered Institute of Housing]] in 1994. The CIH is a professional body for those working in the housing profession in the UK and overseas.<ref>[http://www.cih.org/about/history.htm "History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721062420/http://www.cih.org/about/history.htm |date=21 July 2011 }}, Chartered Institute of Housing, accessed 15 November 2010</ref> The training that Hill gave to Charity Organisation Society volunteers contributed to the development of modern social work, and COS continued to be instrumental in developing social work as a profession during the twentieth century. COS is still in operation today as the charity [[Family Action]].<ref>[http://www.family-action.org.uk/section.aspx?id=1155 "1880s"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718211919/http://www.family-action.org.uk/section.aspx?id=1155 |date=18 July 2011 }}, Family Action, accessed 15 November 2010</ref>
In 1907, Parliament passed the first National Trust Act, enshrining the trust's permanent purpose and giving it powers to protect property for the benefit of the nation. The trust now looks after a wide range of coast, countryside and historic buildings. According to the trust's website, "Staff, volunteers and tenants are engaged daily in providing access to open spaces for people's enjoyment, providing habitats for wildlife and in improving our environment – 'for ever, for everyone'."<ref>[http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-chl/w-countryside_environment.htm "For ever for everyone"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122121035/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-chl/w-countryside_environment.htm |date=22 November 2010 }}, The National Trust, accessed 16 November 2010</ref>
Commemorations of Hill herself include a monument to her at a [[Surrey]] beauty spot, on the summit of a hill called [[Hydon Ball]] (now owned by the National Trust). Shortly after her death, the family erected a stone seat there, from which walkers can enjoy views over the Surrey countryside. The Octavia Hill Society was set up in 1992 "to promote awareness of the ideas and ideals of Octavia Hill, her family, fellow workers and their relevance in today's society nationally and internationally".<ref>[http://octaviahill.org/the-octavia-hill-society.html "Octavia Hill Society"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609155157/http://octaviahill.org/the-octavia-hill-society.html |date=9 June 2010 }}, The Octavia Hill Society, accessed 16 November 2010</ref> Under the society's auspices her birthplace at Wisbech has been turned into the Octavia Hill Birthplace Museum. In 1995, to mark the centenary of the National Trust, a new variety of rose, "Octavia Hill", was named in her honour.<ref>[http://www.rosesuk.com/rose_locator/roses/repeat_flowering_shrub/1231_octavia_hill.php "Octavia Hill"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129114809/http://rosesuk.com/rose_locator/roses/repeat_flowering_shrub/1231_octavia_hill.php |date=29 November 2010 }}, Roses UK, accessed 16 November 2010</ref> <!--WP:CITEVAR There is a carved monument to Hill in Holy Trinity Church at [[Crockham Hill]], Kent: she is represented as "a little old lady in a shawl".<ref name="Newman242">{{Harvnb|Newman|1969|p=242.}}</ref>-->
